cheatsheet:
Access Control
- private limits access to the enclosing scope
- internal is the default (module-wide)
- public/open expose APIs outside the module
hints: private limits access to the type; internal is the default.
lesson:
Lesson: Access Control
Access control limits who can use each symbol.

Overview:
- `private`: current scope.
- `fileprivate`: current file.
- `internal`: default, module scope.
- `public/open`: visible outside module.

Example:
    public struct Kiln {
        public private(set) var temperature: Int = 0
    }

Guidelines:
- Start restrictive and open only what is needed.
- Use `private(set)` for read-only public state.
title: Access Control 1

cheatsheet:
Access Control
- private limits access to the enclosing scope
- internal is the default (module-wide)
- public/open expose APIs outside the module
hints: public exposes types outside the module; open allows subclassing.
lesson:
Lesson: Access Control
Access control limits who can use each symbol.

Overview:
- `private`: current scope.
- `fileprivate`: current file.
- `internal`: default, module scope.
- `public/open`: visible outside module.

Example:
    public struct Kiln {
        public private(set) var temperature: Int = 0
    }

Guidelines:
- Start restrictive and open only what is needed.
- Use `private(set)` for read-only public state.
title: Access Control 2

description: Use errors in a protocol-based API
hints: Throw errors when constraints are not met.
lesson:
Lesson: Errors
Swift errors model expected failure paths.

Overview:
- Define error enums conforming to `Error`.
- Throw from functions marked `throws`.
- Handle with `do/try/catch`.

Example:
    enum HeatError: Error { case tooHot }
    func validate(_ t: Int) throws {
        if t > 1600 { throw HeatError.tooHot }
    }

Guidelines:
- Throw meaningful, typed errors.
- Use `try?` only when silent fallback is intentional.
title: Error Integration

cheatsheet:
Generics
- Use <T> to make functions and types reusable
- Constraints limit T to specific protocols
- where adds extra requirements
hints: Generics let you reuse logic across types.
lesson:
Lesson: Generics
Generics let one implementation work across many types safely.

Overview:
- Use type parameters like `<T>`.
- Add constraints (`T: Protocol`) to require behavior.
- Use `where` clauses for multi-type relationships.

Example:
    func firstMatch<T: Equatable>(_ items: [T], _ value: T) -> Int? {
        items.firstIndex(of: value)
    }

Guidelines:
- Introduce generics when duplication appears.
- Keep generic APIs readable with clear names.
title: Generic Function

cheatsheet:
Protocols
- Define required properties and methods
- Types conform by implementing requirements
- Protocols can be used as types
hints: Use protocols to define behavior and extensions for defaults.
lesson:
Lesson: Protocols
Protocols define capabilities without choosing a concrete type.

Overview:
- Declare requirements for properties and methods.
- Conforming types provide implementations.
- Use protocol values to decouple call sites from concrete types.

Example:
    protocol HeatSource {
        func output() -> Int
    }

Guidelines:
- Keep protocols focused.
- Model behavior, not storage details.
title: Model Layer Exercise

cheatsheet:
Memory
- strong references keep instances alive
- weak breaks reference cycles
- Use [weak self] in closures to avoid leaks
hints: Weak references prevent strong reference cycles.
lesson:
Lesson: Memory Management
Swift uses ARC to manage object lifetime for class instances.

Overview:
- Strong references keep objects alive.
- Cycles cause leaks when two objects strongly retain each other.
- Use `weak` (or `unowned` when safe) to break cycles.

Example:
    class A { weak var b: B? }
    class B { var a: A? }

Guidelines:
- Use `[weak self]` in escaping closures where needed.
- Favor structs for independent value data.
title: ARC Safety

cheatsheet:
Structs
- struct Name { var property: Type }
- Instances: let/var value = Name(...)
- Properties use dot syntax
- var instance required to mutate properties
hints: Structs are copied on assignment.
lesson:
Lesson: Structs
Structs are value types used to model data with clear ownership.

Overview:
- Define stored properties in `struct Name { ... }`.
- Add methods to keep behavior close to data.
- Use `mutating` on methods that change `self`.

Example:
    struct Reading {
        var temp: Int
        mutating func cool(by amount: Int) { temp -= amount }
    }

Guidelines:
- Prefer `let` for immutable instances.
- Use computed properties for derived values.
solution:
copy.thickness = 5
print(original.thickness)
print(copy.thickness)
title: Struct Copy Drill

cheatsheet:
Structs
- struct Name { var property: Type }
- Instances: let/var value = Name(...)
- Properties use dot syntax

hints: Mutating methods can change stored properties.
lesson:
Lesson: Structs
Structs are value types used to model data with clear ownership.

Overview:
- Define stored properties in `struct Name { ... }`.
- Add methods to keep behavior close to data.
- Use `mutating` on methods that change `self`.

Example:
    struct Reading {
        var temp: Int
        mutating func cool(by amount: Int) { temp -= amount }
    }

Guidelines:
- Prefer `let` for immutable instances.
- Use computed properties for derived values.
title: Mutating Counter

cheatsheet:
Properties
- Stored properties hold values
- Computed properties use get/set
- willSet/didSet observe changes
- lazy defers initialization
- static creates type-level members
hints: Set should convert pounds back to kg.
lesson:
Lesson: Properties
Properties define how types store and expose state.

Overview:
- Stored properties keep values.
- Computed properties derive values with `get` and optional `set`.
- Property observers (`willSet`/`didSet`) react to changes.
- `lazy` defers expensive initialization.

Example:
    struct Batch {
        var items: Int
        var doubled: Int { items * 2 }
    }

Guidelines:
- Keep computed properties fast and side-effect free.
- Use observers for lightweight bookkeeping only.
title: Computed Conversion

cheatsheet:
Properties
- Stored properties hold values
- Computed properties use get/set
- willSet/didSet observe changes
- lazy defers initialization
- static creates type-level members
expectedOutput:
Will set to 3
Did set from 1
hints: Use newValue and oldValue in observers.
lesson:
Lesson: Properties
Properties define how types store and expose state.

Overview:
- Stored properties keep values.
- Computed properties derive values with `get` and optional `set`.
- Property observers (`willSet`/`didSet`) react to changes.
- `lazy` defers expensive initialization.

Example:
    struct Batch {
        var items: Int
        var doubled: Int { items * 2 }
    }

Guidelines:
- Keep computed properties fast and side-effect free.
- Use observers for lightweight bookkeeping only.
title: Observer Echo

cheatsheet:
Classes
- class Name { var property: Type }
- Classes are reference types
- deinit runs when an instance is released
hints: Classes share a single instance across references.
lesson:
Lesson: Classes
Classes are reference types, so multiple variables can point to one instance.

Overview:
- `class` supports inheritance and `deinit`.
- Assignment copies the reference, not the data.
- Use classes when shared mutable state is intentional.

Example:
    class Furnace {
        var level = 0
    }
    let a = Furnace()
    let b = a
    b.level = 3   // a.level is also 3

Guidelines:
- Be explicit about ownership.
- Watch for unintended shared mutation.
solution:
secondary.mode = "Active"
print(primary.mode)
title: Class Shared State

cheatsheet:
Extensions
- Add methods or computed properties to existing types
- Protocol extensions can provide defaults
description: Add a method with an extension
hints: Extensions can add methods to existing types.
lesson:
Lesson: Extensions
Extensions add behavior to existing types without subclassing.

Overview:
- Add methods, computed properties, and protocol conformance.
- Keep related helpers grouped by purpose.
- Protocol extensions can provide default behavior.

Example:
    extension Int {
        var isHot: Bool { self >= 1400 }
    }

Guidelines:
- Prefer extensions for organization and reuse.
- Avoid hiding critical behavior across too many files.
title: Extension Helper

Overview:
- Use type parameters like `<T>`.

Example:
    func firstMatch<T: Equatable>(_ items: [T], _ value: T) -> Int? {
        items.firstIndex(of: value)
    }

Guidelines:
- Introduce generics when duplication appears.
- Keep generic APIs readable with clear names.
solution:
let bin = Bin(item: "Iron")
print(bin.item)
title: Protocol Associated

cheatsheet:
Protocols
- Define required properties and methods
- Types conform by implementing requirements
- Protocols can be used as types
hints: Use 'any' to spell an existential.
Access heat through the protocol-typed value.
lesson:
Lesson: Protocols
Protocols define capabilities without choosing a concrete type.

Overview:
- Declare requirements for properties and methods.
- Conforming types provide implementations.
- Use protocol values to decouple call sites from concrete types.

Example:
    protocol HeatSource {
        func output() -> Int
    }

Guidelines:
- Keep protocols focused.
- Model behavior, not storage details.
solution:
let source: any HeatSource = Burner(heat: 1500)
print(source.heat)
title: Protocol Erasure

cheatsheet:
Generics
- Use <T> to make functions and types reusable
- Constraints limit T to specific protocols
- where adds extra requirements
description: Constrain a generic method with where
hints: Use a where clause on the method, not the type.
lesson:
Lesson: Generics
Generics let one implementation work across many types safely.

Overview:
- Use type parameters like `<T>`.
- Add constraints (`T: Protocol`) to require behavior.
- Use `where` clauses for multi-type relationships.

Example:
    func firstMatch<T: Equatable>(_ items: [T], _ value: T) -> Int? {
        items.firstIndex(of: value)
    }

Guidelines:
- Introduce generics when duplication appears.
- Keep generic APIs readable with clear names.
title: Where Method

title: Generic Extension

cheatsheet:
Memory
- strong references keep instances alive
- weak breaks reference cycles
- Use [weak self] in closures to avoid leaks
hints: Capture weakly to avoid a strong cycle.
Use nil coalescing to print "nil" when missing.
lesson:
Lesson: Memory Management
Swift uses ARC to manage object lifetime for class instances.

Overview:
- Strong references keep objects alive.
- Cycles cause leaks when two objects strongly retain each other.
- Use `weak` (or `unowned` when safe) to break cycles.

Example:
    class A { weak var b: B? }
    class B { var a: A? }

Guidelines:
- Use `[weak self]` in escaping closures where needed.
- Favor structs for independent value data.
title: Weak Release

cheatsheet:
Extensions
- Add methods or computed properties to existing types
- Protocol extensions can provide defaults
description: Add a computed property via extension
hints: Extensions can add computed properties.
Return a Bool based on weight.
lesson:
Lesson: Extensions
Extensions add behavior to existing types without subclassing.

Overview:
- Add methods, computed properties, and protocol conformance.
- Keep related helpers grouped by purpose.
- Protocol extensions can provide default behavior.

Example:
    extension Int {
        var isHot: Bool { self >= 1400 }
    }

Guidelines:
- Prefer extensions for organization and reuse.
- Avoid hiding critical behavior across too many files.
title: Extension Computed

hints: rethrows forwards errors from the closure.
Handle the error in the catch block.
lesson:
Lesson: Errors
Swift errors model expected failure paths.

Overview:
- Define error enums conforming to `Error`.
- Throw from functions marked `throws`.
- Handle with `do/try/catch`.

Example:
    enum HeatError: Error { case tooHot }
    func validate(_ t: Int) throws {
        if t > 1600 { throw HeatError.tooHot }
    }

Guidelines:
- Throw meaningful, typed errors.
- Use `try?` only when silent fallback is intentional.
title: Rethrow
